author: cbc
title: 'We're all humans': U.S. border agent watches as asylum-seekers cross into Canada
text:
The agents who patrol the Canada-U.S. border in Quebec say it's been hard for them to watch as families of refugees trudge through snow and freezing conditions to flee to Canada.
Montreal becomes 'sanctuary city' for after unanimous vote RCMP help asylum-seeking family through snow after run-in with U.S. border patrol "We're all humans," says Brad Curtis, the acting division chief of a local U.S. border patrol.
He's standing in a snowy ditch on the U.S. side of the border near Roxham Road in Hemmingford, Que., speaking to a group of journalists who've gathered for a media tour in light of the influx of illegal border crossings.
"We've seen untold things â€” babies ... I wish there was a simple solution," he says.
RCMP loads asylum-seeker's baby stroller into cruiser 0:53
Curtis shakes the hand of his Canadian counterpart for the cameras, careful not to step over the invisible line that divides them.
Only a half an hour earlier, a family with a baby crossed that line in the February sunshine.
Agents reassured the family members as they were taken into custody to head to a processing centre.
One member of the RCMP loaded bags and a baby carriage into the back of the police vehicle before it drove off.
Staff Sgt. Brian Byrne of Canada's Border Integrity Program and Federal Detachments says it's touching to see what these families go through.
"I'm a father of two myself," Byrne says.
"Some of these people have long journeys. They look fairly tired. Usually [they're] not well dressed for the climate here."
A sign on the U.S. side of the border at Roxham Road in Champlain, N.Y. warns pedestrians, in French and English, to go no further. This is one of the places where asylum-seekers have been crossing into Canada regularly. (Jaela Bernstien/CBC)
Families such as the one that arrived on Monday morning are taken to a building near the official border crossing in Lacolle, seven kilometres away.
Inside they'll be interviewed, fingerprinted, asked to fill out some paperwork and then, more often than not, the new arrivals are released on a promise to appear at their refugee hearing.
Inland Enforcement Officer Dominique Fillion says there are three reasons they will detain people who have crossed illegally: if they don't have proper documentation and so can't be identified, if they are deemed to be a threat, or if there's reason to believe they won't show up at their hearing.
Otherwise, they're allowed to walk away after processing.
Border agents say refugees can stay with family or friends, or they're given a list of shelters where they can stay until their hearing date.
Quebec sees biggest increase in illegal crossings from U.S., RCMP says A helicopter patrols the Canada-U.S. border above Hemmingford, Que. and Champlain, N.Y. (Jaela Bernstien/CBC)
